title: 103_hr4759
content: The Act titled the "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994" aims to enhance mathematics and science education by involving outstanding teachers in government programs. The Department of Energy's capabilities in these areas are recognized, and the need for collaboration between federal agencies and the education community is emphasized. A pilot program has shown the effectiveness of having these teachers in professional staff roles in Congress. The Act establishes a national fellowship program for exceptional math and science teachers, known as "Albert Einstein Fellows". The Act defines key terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit educational organization selected by the Secretary, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" for math or science teachers who have received specific recognitions. The Act defines key terms and criteria for math or science teachers to qualify for a fellowship program, including receiving national or State recognition and taking a sabbatical leave from teaching. The term "secondary school" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Fellowship Program is authorized under Section 5 of the Act, which sets criteria for math or science teachers to qualify, including national or State recognition and taking a sabbatical leave from teaching. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program allows the Secretary to provide 10 outstanding math or science teachers with fellowships each fiscal year, with the possibility of reducing the number of fellowships based on funding. Priority is given to individuals selected under specific criteria if the number of fellowships is reduced. The Secretary provides fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers for a 10-month period, coinciding with the academic year. Fellowships are allocated to various government departments and agencies, including the Senate, House of Representatives, Department of Energy, Department of Education, National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation, Office of Science and Technology Policy, and NASA. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program is administered by a contractor authorized by the Secretary. The contractor is responsible for managing the application process, promoting the program to teachers in various recognition programs, and overseeing the fellowship program. The responsibilities of the contractor for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program include screening applicants, selecting fellowship recipients, organizing orientation programs, managing reporting and evaluation, and submitting annual reports. The contractor for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program is responsible for establishing and administering a reporting and evaluation program, submitting annual reports to the Secretary, and managing all funds received under the Act, including salaries and expenses. Funds can only be used for fellowship recipient salaries and the contractor's Federal insurance contributions. The contractor for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program can use funds for fellowship recipient salaries, administrative expenses, relocation expenses, and conducting final selection interviews. They can also seek funding from non-Federal sources for travel and professional meeting expenses. The contractor invites semifinalists to Washington, D.C., for interviews after the initial screening process, with final selections made thereafter. The Albert Einstein Fellowship Program contractor invites semifinalists to Washington, D.C., for interviews after the initial screening process. Final selections are made by key officials and announced before May 1 for each fellowship term. Each fellowship recipient selected by key officials will be assigned to the Senate or a specific department, agency, institute, or office. Final placement involves interviewing within the designated placement area before the fellowship period begins. SEC. 6. Fellowship recipients will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-13 of the General Schedule. SEC. 7. $550,000 authorized for fiscal year 1995, with additional funds for fiscal years 1996-2001 to implement the Act.
